text: The silence of a peaceful prairie at dusk. The sky shades of purple and orange. Short grass, rolling hills. Faint howls of coyotes in the distance. A small figure breaks the stillness. Brady walks across the plains wearing a hospital gown an cowboy boots. He has a gauze on the right side of his hea Fresh bruises around his eyes. He has run away from the hospital, dazed and tired from the long walk. He splashes through a stream of mud and horse shit. He walks towards the warm orange light of the trailer hou in the distance. INT. BRADY'S TRAILER - LIVING ROOM — MORNING Brady walks into the dim living room. The light flickers. is pale, covered in sweat and out of breath.

Dad? He stands still. No answer. INT. BRADY'S TRAILER - LILLY’S ROOM - MORNING Brady walks in and finds his little sister LILLY asleep. is 14 year old, bright, spirited and on the brink of womanhood. She has Asperger's Syndrome.
Hey Lillian... Do you know where dad is? Lilly is still half-asleep.
No...
Ok... Go back to sleep.

Brady wakes up in bed covered in sweat. INT. BRADY’S TRAILER - BATHROOM - MORNING Brady throws up in the toilet bowl. He takes a handful of prescription medication.  3. The bloody gauze is stapled to his head. He feels the sta with his fingers, taking deep breaths and begins to pull out of his head with a hunting knife. The bloody staples drop onto the counter one by one. The fresh wound, stitched together on the back of his sha head is shocking. It looks fresh and raw.
Brady wraps his head with plastic wrap and takes a shower awkwardly, taking care that his head doesn’t get wet.
Brady walks through the messy living room towards the fluorescent glow in the kitchen.

Brady waits as the coffee brews, spacing out. He takes a sip of the hot coffee. Another sip. His right hand twitches suddenly and starts to shake. Surprised, he quickly grabs it with his left hand, but dr the coffee cup. It shatters to the ground, coffee spillin across the cracked vinyl floor. Panicked and confused, Brady shakes his hand. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - MORNING In the blue dawn, Brady can be seen from a distance, walk from the little trailer towards the corral, where a pale horse is tied up. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - CORRAL - MORNING Brady pets GUS, his favorite horse and oldest companion. He’s a large, and magnificent, pale colored Palomino. The love between them is clear. Brady’s hand runs through Gus’s smooth coat.
It’s good to see you Gus.  Brady notices a cut on Gus’s leg.
What did you get yourself into? He checks the wound nervously.

Fighting over mares again? You're lucky it wasn’t any deeper. He wraps his arms around Gus’ neck, like a child that has been away from home too long. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - FRONT YARD - MORNING Brady practices lassoing with a ranch rope. He’s rusty, missing the target repeatedly. An old pick-up pulls up. WAYNE, Brady’s father, an old-sc cowboy wearing a black denim jacket and cowboy hat, comes back drunk. Brady is not happy to see him.
What the hell are you doing here? Brady ignores him. WAYNE (CONT’D) I seen Tanner at the bar and he said you escaped. Wayne giggles as he climbs out of the pick-up.
Told you to check me out.
Doctors said you had to stay, buddy. Wayne goes up to Brady. WAYNE (CONT’D) Give me a hug. Brady backs away.
Why don’t you just go inside and sober up?

Sober up!? Let me see you rope that. Wayne points at the plastic steer dummy. WAYNE (CONT’D) Checking yourself out of the hospital like your uncle Rowdy? Annoyed, Brady ropes anyway and misses it again. Wayne starts laughing. WAYNE (CONT’D) What the hell? Can’t you rope anymore? Maybe you should’ve stayed in the hospital. Taking a deep breath. Brady ignores him. WAYNE (CONT’D) You got any chew? Brady sighs, takes his tobacco chew out of his pocket and tosses it to Wayne. Wayne puts the chew in his mouth and walks up to Brady ag WAYNE (CONT’D) Just give me a hug. Brady lets his father hug him. His expression is blank. WAYNE (CONT’D) Your hat and chaps are in the backseat. Love ya... Wayne staggers away into the house. Brady watches him for moment before going back to roping again. INT. BRADY’S TRAILER - BRADY’S ROOM - MORNING Brady puts his rodeo hat on the panelled wall. He takes h leather chaps and his spurs out of a black trash bag. He sits on the edge of the bed and cleans them.
Brady plays cards alone at the table. Wayne, sobered up, makes three microwaved burgers (Chuck Wagons).
Lil, Lilla! Hustle!! Wayne calls Lilly to come eat.
Be quiet! Lilly walks in a small voice recorder and an apple.
Are you ready?
Ready for what?
To eat!
No! Just point down! Lilly goes to sit down despite her protests.
I’m just doesn’t no understand. And I can’t use to imagine that.
There’s supper. You better have a bit of that Chuck Wagon.
No way! I don’t like it! Wayne puts the soggy microwaved burger in front of her.
Just look at it. Just look at it for a second. Lilly stares at it.
No. I’m sick of it. She pushes it away and looks over at Brady.
But I can’t do anything and it’s making me all mad. Now it’s a dream and it’s not a plan as well.
Ok, ok. I will make a deal with you. A bite of the Chuck Wagon or... wear a bra.
But I don’t like that bra ever!
Brady, get her that bra.
You shouldn’t try to force her to eat things she doesn’t wanna eat.
She has to eat something and this is the only food we got.
No way! I don’t like it! Just BS!
You're stubborn just like your brother. Look how he ended up!
That’s dirty.
Big old gash on the side of his head. I told you not to go and ride that son-of-a-bitch anyway.
Yah well, I would’ve won the rodeo if I had got her rode. Wayne looks away for a moment.
Excuse me, guys...
Whole point is... I told you to stay home. Wayne chucks down his beer. Brady stares blankly into his burger.

The Blackburn family grave yard - a cluster of wooden crosses. Some ancient and some new. Rusted horseshoes and weathered cowboy boots are scattere around the long grass. Brady opens the barbwire gate. A bell tied to the metal, chimes gently as he closes it behind him. Brady prays silently in front of his mother’s grave. On t wooden cross it reads: Mari Blackburn. 1963-2013. A few children’s star stickers pasted on the weathered wood. Lilly’s handy work. Brady looks up at the wooden cross.

I was tough, mom. The sound of bell chimes and long grass blowing in the wi Brady sits there and listens. INT. BRADY’S BEDROOM - DAY Brady is trying to take a nap. The wound on the side of h head looks dried up. He can hear Lilly’s laughter. Lilly walks in.
What’s the matter Brady? She sees his wound.
Oh boy. Oh poor Brady.
Sit down, Lil. Brady grabs her hand and pulls her to sit down. She touch his shoulders gently while inspecting his wound.
You won’t get hurt yourself...
I didn’t mean to.
It’s ok. Come here.  Lilly gives him a hug.
Listen... This time... You don’t... Lilly struggles to find her words.
You don’t hurt boo boo?
Yah. She points at Brady’s wound.
This is a head.
Yah.
It’s called ‘skull’.
Yah. I hurt my skull. You know what they had to do? They had to do surgery.
Surgery?! Don’t joke me.
You know what they do when they do surgery?
What?
What do they do?
Got broke.
Yah. Broke my skull.
Yah. Broke my skull.  10.
And you have to cut it with a knife. Then they put a plate in there and then they sew it up.
But, but, but you said...
I’m not gonna... not gonna what?
Bucking horse anymore.
Uh... Maybe. Lilly looks upset.
I’m not gonna die.
Nope! I’m not gonna die either. I’m staying alive!
Toughest cowgirl.

Uh huh. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - NIGHT The sound of crickets and horned toads in the darkness. Brady walks down the wooden steps leading to the front do He sits on the last step, in the dreary porch light, and spits at the dirt. He is tired but he can’t sleep. EXT. BRADY’S TRAILER - CORRAL - DAY Brady walks towards the corral wearing his leather rodeo jacket. His eye is still bruised and he looks tired as he Wayne is trying a bay horse, while the horse’s owner, FRA is watching. Frank is an old-school rancher cowboy with r skin and a hook for a hand.
He’s really moving good...  Frank Wayne 11.
How you doing Frank?
Hey Brady, how you doing?
Shit... I’m healing up. checks out Brady’s head.
Looks pretty wicked there... rides over. He’s cocky and knows how much Brady hates watching other people ride his horses.
Frank. This idiot for a horse trainer you have ran away from the hospital four days after the surgery.
Hey... Damn kid...
Don’t listen to anything he says. He may not be thinking too good. The older cowboys laughs. Brady bites his tongue. Wayne Wayne Brady Wayne
(to Wayne) You got him backing up pretty good? makes a kissing sound and starts backing the horse up.
Halt baba. pulls hard. The horse takes a few steps back. watches intensively.
You should lay off that horse’s face a little bit. Then he wouldn’t be putting his head there like a goose. rides around and looks at Brady patronizingly.  12.
You can tell me what to do when you're riding the son-of-a-bitch. Too bad you went to the rodeo and got all fucked up. Frank watches the father and son bickering as if he has s it many times.
Well I was doing what I...
I’m doing your work here!
I was doing what I fucking needed to do, aright?!
Well, I’m doing what I need to do. Finishing something you should be doing. Brady can’t argue with that and looks away.

Brady sits alone on the sofa, watching rodeo videos on TV young cowboy is riding a black bucking horse. INT. BRADY’S BEDROOM - DAY Brady is taking a nap. The door cracks open. Brady’s rodeo friends, CAT, TANNER JAMES sneak in. They’re a classic bunch of young Indian cowboys, donned in cowboy hats, denim and flannel shirts. They bend over excitedly, checking out Brady’s scar, talk in low whispers.
Holy piss!
Jesus Christ. He looks like Frankenstein.
It’s fuckin’ rank.  13.
Fuck that. That’s just a scratch. James takes the drag of his cigarette.
A little smoke will help. He leans forward and blows the smoke into Brady’s face. B flinches and wakes up. Everyone laughs. Brady pushes James.
Get the fuck out of here. Brady rubs his eyes, half smiling.
You can wrap it up right?
Why? What’re you guys doing?
Put your wranglers on man.
Yah. Let’s go get fucked up! Brady nods. The boys are already at the door.
Last of the Mohicans! Brady laughs and sits up.

The epic landscape of the Badlands at dusk. The boys have built a campfire on one of the large rocks. They are laughing, jumping over the fire and being rowdy. The boys race up a steep hill, the half moon is bright in darkening sky above them.
Come on Brady! Brady sits back near the glow of the fire. He watches the they run up to the top.  14. Brady doesn’t follow.
It’s dark now and the boys are huddled around the camp fi sipping from beer bottles and talking about their rodeo injuries with great pride in the flickering glow of the f

That horse I got on in Fargo... Everything I heard about her was shit. But got on her and said ‘fuck it’. She was good out there for a while, until the whistle, she got real trashy and started turning there by the fence. I went over the front of her. She stepped on my head. Popped me out. Didn’t knock me out til I got to the hospital. I had a seizure and went into a coma.
Broke my thumb. Broke wrist twice. Broke my ankle. I mean I died eight times, that’s why they call me Cat. Didn't even cry or anything... Igmu! (Lakota for “Cat”)
Got kicked in Kadoka at Rodeo Bible Camp. Went out of the back door. That wasn’t so bad. Was just kind of a stinger for a week.

Got on this great big grey mare. I was getting pretty stretched out in the end. Thank god I heard the whistle blow. Right at the end she slammed me down on the dirt. Hardest I ever been slammed before. Broke three ribs on my right side. Brady over there, told me to get on my short go horse, even though my ribs hurt like a son-of-a-bitch. Brady looks up at Tanner who is pretty drunk. TANNER (CONT’D) Ain't that right Brady? You don’t let no pain put you down. (MORE )
You ain’t gonna be turning out horses left and right just because your head hurts a little bit, are you? Cat looks at the boys thoughtfully.
I’m not, I’m drawing out of anything. I’m just taking some time off. Your brain is a little different than yo ur ribs...
Yah I know. It’s all the same to a cowboy. Ride through the pain. Brady keeps quiet but his jaws are tense.
Now don’t let this head injury go to your head. Get you scared. I know how that goes with some guys. They get scared to get on again, and they end up becoming farmers...
Hey Brady... Cat interrupts the conversation and turns to Brady.
You seen Lane lately?

I didn’t get a chance to see him there for a while, while I was rodeoing. But they just checked him into a brand new rehab facility. Cat looks back at the fire, lost in a thought. Tanner wipes his face, looks restless after the mention o Lane.
He probably could’ve won the world if he’d had an honest chance. He was a damn good bull rider. Tanner stuffs tobacco chew into his lip.  16.
Remember when he went three for three in McCool Junction? And won it? Brady smiles and nods.
That was a good night for Lane. You remember when he switched hands at Elkhorn and won the bull riding first time ever riding a bull with his right hand? Eighty four points!

Shit, one time me and Lane was coming back from a party. We was driving in Tanner's brother's car, and we was kind of talking about women. We was a little drunk and Lane looks over at me and says ‘James, you know what one thing I’ve learned in life is’ he says ‘girls, they come in with a name and they leave with a number’. James and the other boys laugh.
Kind of fucked up, but...
Dirty dog!
Yep. Lane. The laughter fades and the boys become sombre. Cat looks at the fire.
Real wild. Real good guy too. Brady looks over at Cat.

I want to say a prayer for him, I mean, it would be best if we said a prayer every day, you know, the guy sure could use it. But I want to go ahead and just say... Brady pulls his hood back. Tanner and James remove their hats. They bow their heads in prayer.  17.
I pray to God that he takes in all the strength from all his friends across the nation. North, south, east and west, ‘cause over this country. Cat has a thoughtful smile on his face.
I hope he gets to ride again. Feel the wind in his back, watch it flow through the grass. Be what he wants to be, once again. Brady listens. His jaw tightens.

We are him and he is us. We’re all one in this together. Mitakuye Oyasin. Brady crosses himself. Tanner and James put their hats ba on and take swigs from their beer bottles. Cat picks up his guitar and starts strumming the chords o country song he wrote called “Gambling Man” about the lif a rodeo cowboy. It used to be Brady’s favorite now it’s bittersweet for him to listen to. Brady stares into the fire, watching the eerie blue flame curl around the glowing embers.

Music plays as time passes. Moments of silence on the Gre Plains. A Badlands sunrise. Withering sunflowers in a fie of dry grass. Windmills. Horses at dusk. Brady wanders in the Badlands while a thunderstorm is bre in the distance, coloring the sky an unusual blend of yel and green. A significant amount of time has passed since the boys pr for their friend around the bonfire. Brady’s hair has gro back, covering up his scar. He looks thin and pale. He watches the distance lightening.
Brady's truck speeds along the highway. Not a soul for mi  18.
Brady is driving. He looks restless and nervous.
Brady walks through glass doors of a physical rehabilitat center and stops at the front desk.
Hello, Ma’‘am. I’m here to see Lane Scott.
Brady walks down the hallway looking for Lane’s room. INT. LANE’S ROOM - DAY Brady walks in and sees LANE sitting alone in the middle the room in his wheelchair.

Hey, brother, how you doing? He walks over to Lane’s chair. The room is sparse, with a small bed in the corner, a white support pole beside it leading into the ceiling. The walls are covered in old pictures of Lane in his younger years as an up-and-coming bull rider. Lane can not speak. His bull riding accident has left him permanently paralyzed. He’s barely able to lift his left hand, using sign language to communicate. Brady gives Lane a hug, helping him to put his arm around him.
I missed you, brother. Lane slowly closes his eyes as they embrace. Brady pulls back after a moment.
You're looking good. How you feeling? He looks at Lane’s hand for an answer.  19.
Feeling good huh. It’s a pretty good place here. Lane starts to spell out each letter of the words with hi shaking left hand.
How’s your head?
How’s my head...? Feeling aright... Lane starts to sign again.
Rub some...
Rub some...
...dirt in it. Brady laughs.
And some Copenhagen too huh? Lane slowly smiles and starts to sign. Brady reads it.
R, I, D, E... Ride. Can I ride? Am I able to ride? Lane gives him a thumb up.

Not supposed to for a while. I wish I can ride, but... If I hit that plate in my head, it will cave the whole side of my head in... But... Brady looks down. INT. LANE’S ROOM - A WHILE LATER Brady and Lane watch a video of Lane on YouTube on an iPa
My name is Lane Scott. I’m eighteen years old. I’m from Kennebec, South Dakota.  20.
Lane, he is young, but he is really good. Best bull rider coming out of South Dakota for sure.

I mean... I mean, not trying to apply anything. But, me and superman have not been seen in the same room together, so... Brady smiles and looks up at Lane. Lane smiles back. His is a lot thinner now, than the young, vibrant man in the video. His facial muscle has been damaged by the paralysi altering his looks. But Lane is smiling. He enjoys revisi these moments. The video starts to show Lane’s wild bull rides, chasing after buffaloes, being a goofy teenager. Lane stands in front of camera, wearing a cowboy hat and striped shirt.

I was about three years old when my dad introduced me to the rodeo world. There is nothing can really beat it. You get on a bull. Makes a good ride. Everybody in the stands stand up for you, yells and cheers. Your adrenaline is goin’. You just can’t stop but smiling. Lane, in his wheelchair, eyes bright, grinning happily. H has not lost his spirit.

There is nothing like strapping yourself on a 2000 pound animal and just going with it. That’s what I want to do and I want to do it for the rest of my life. I can’t imagine doing anything else. Brady's smiles slowly fades. INT. BRADY’S TRAILER - BATHROOM - THE NEXT MORNING Brady checks the now healed scar on his head. He brushes hair over to conceal it. He takes a handful of proscription pills.  21. He puts on a necktie. As he pulls the tie through the pin the fingers on his right hand suddenly grip the tie and l onto it. Brady pulls the tie out of the grip and peels his fingers open. He has gotten used to it now, he is not panicking. He shakes his hand and puts his cowboy hat on.
Brady's truck pulls up. He is a little nervous. He checks himself in the mirror.
Stay in here all right Lil?
Ok Brady. Lilly focuses on her recorder.
I believe my pleasure is my favorite thing to do is sing along. Brady takes tobacco chew out of his mouth and throws it o of the window.
Brady sits across the table from HELENA. A Lakota woman w long braids and a strong gaze.
Do you have a resume?
No, ma’am.
Any job experience?
I’m a horse trainer.
You can’t do that right now?
I would... But I can’t for a while, since I’m laid up... So...  22.
Well, you have two options. Oglala Lakota College has a GED program. The OST TERO office has job training program for construction... Road work... Brady can’t help but interrupts her.
I'm looking for something a little more temporary than that. They look at each other.
...-You know, I’m... probably gonna be training horses in a few month.
You still need something to fall back on. You can’t train horses forever. Brady looks away. Helena looks at him for another moment, then she starts writing on a posted.
I have a cousin who is the manager of Dakota Mart. His name is Robbie. They have some temporary positions. Tell him I sent you. Brady takes the posted.
Ok... Thank you. He gets up and walks towards the door.
You look like your mom. Brady stops and looks back to her.
I used to go to high school with her. She was really awesome. Brady nods, forces a smile.  23.
Brady walks across the empty parking lot towards the supermarket.

Brady picks up a bag of candy and looks over at the check He sees TERRI DAWN, a young woman with pink hair and dark eyes. She glances back at him. He quickly looks away. Takes a deep breath and walks towa her. He puts on a smile.
Hi Terri Dawn. Terri Dawn greets him but she is not friendly.
Hi Brady. How are you?
Is the manager here?
No, why?
Never mind... A moment of awkward silence as Terri scans the items. There’s a history between them, and Terri Dawn is playing disinterested.
I didn’t know you worked here. Terri Dawn rolls her eyes.
There’s a lot that you don’t know. Brady hides his annoyance.
So how have you been doing? Terri Dawn ignores him. Another moment passes.  24.
I'm dating your friend Tanner, just so you know. Brady looks at her, not sure what to say.
Brady quickly searches his wallet. EXT. BRADY’S TRUCK - EVENING Brady drives as Lilly is singing, the sun setting behind
Lil, I’m thinking about going to the rodeo. Do you wanna go with? Lilly looks up at Brady and shakes her head.
No. Nope.
Take you to the carnival after? Get on some rides?
Carnival? Oh boy. Yes!

The announcers voice echoes out over the rodeo grounds. Brady walks towards the glow of the flood lights above th stadium, and makes his way behind the chute. Cat and the other RODEO BOYS are surprised but happy to s him. They shake his hand and check out his scar. Brady sits back and restlessly watches everyone getting ready. He looks over at Tanner, who is getting ready for bareback ride. Tanner gives Brady the finger. Brady shake his head and looks away. The Lakota Flag Song is sung over the speakers. Brady and boys listens with their hats off in respect. Tanner climbs into the chute, onto his horse. The horse starts to buck, rattling the steel bars, showing its powe and aggression.  25. Brady and the boys steady it. The whistle blows. The gate opens. The bucking horse charges out and Tanner rides it into the arena. Brady and the boys cheer loudly for him as he rides 8 seconds. A perfect ride. The crowd cheers. The other riders soon follow. Brady watches a young rider gallop across the arena on his horse with envy. He wishes was out there too.

Brady sits on a plastic horse on a carousel, feeling both nauseous and mortified. It feels like a bad joke. Lilly happily sits beside him, singing on her horse with hands in the air. The spinning gives Brady a bad headache. Bright lights fl by in a blur of motion, overwhelming him.

Loud music. Neon lights. Rowdy cowboys. Brady is sitting in the corner booth, dazed from his headaches, watching Tanner, Terri Dawn and Cat talking fr across the table. Tanner is gloating about the 8 seconds ride he made today He checks on Lilly, who is sitting at the bar watching Se Street videos on her phone with James beside her. James playfully takes Lilly’s soda and she wrestles it ba Brady looks down. Having a hard time keeping his eyes ope
Hey, wake up grandpa! Tanner slams on the table.
Falling asleep over there! Are you gonna enter for Water’s Rodeo on the 17th?
Yah. Brady nods, although this is probably unlikely.
I‘ll be ready to ride by then.
Hell ya man. It’d be good.. Terri Dawn slaps Tanners arm real hard, surprising everyo
Tanner, quit that! He just got hurt. Come on now.
What’s wrong with that? His head is a long way from his heart. He won’t hurt it again.
But he has a metal plate in his head. Brady is annoyed and embarrassed Terri is talking for him about his injury. He can defend himself.
So?! Metal ain’t supposed to bend. He'll be fine. They both look over at Brady for a moment.
It’s too fucking dangerous...
Why don’t you just mind your own fucking business? Terri Dawn stares at Brady. Brady looks away.
You know what? Fuck you. Terri Dawn, wounded, gets up and walks over to the bar. Tanner smirks. He gets up too.
Yah. Fuck you Brady. It’s ‘DANGEROUS’ .  27. Watching Tanner leave. Cat smiles and gives Brady a nudge
Don’t worry about it. Brady sighs, trying to shrug it off.
Howdy. BILL, an older cowboy, white hair beneath his hat, and a tooth pick in his cheek, sits down opposite Brady.
Are you Brady Blackburn?
Yah.
Bill. Brady shakes Bill’s hand.

I heard you’re a horse trainer. I have a colt nobody can break. Will you come and look at him? Brady looks over at the bar and sees Tanner sitting next Lilly and playfully talking to her. Lilly is still laughing at her Sesame Street video.
Aren’t you way too old to be watching Sesame Street? When I was 15 I was at the bar drinking with my dad. Lilly ignores him and stares at her video.

Ya thirsty? You should have some of this stuff. Tanner hands Lilly his half-drunk beer. Lilly laughs and pushes the beer away. Bill is still trying to convince Brady to train his horse Brady is barely listening.  28.
So, what do you think? Will you come and look at him? Brady looks back to Bill.
Yah, maybe, in a couple of weeks, I got my head caved in...
I don’t like to! He looks over at Tanner and Lilly again, his patience is wearing thin. Tanner tickles Lilly and pushes the beer bottle into her hand. She laughs and pushes it away again.
Come on! You can have a beer! Brady suddenly gets up and charges up to the bar.
This is way better for you than that crap you drink... Brady grabs Tanner by the collar and shoves him HARD.
What the fuck do you think you’re doing?! Tanner is shocked and grabs Brady by the shirt, pushing h back as others try to react.

What the fuck man?! What you want?! Terri Dawn quickly takes Lilly's arm and they head outsid the bar. TANNER (CONT’D) I wasn’t doing nothin’! I wasn’t doing nothin’ Brady! Cat and the other cowboys pull them apart. Tanner’s cowboy hat falls to the ground. Red-faced and ruffled, he tries to compose himself.  29.

Fuck you! I didn’t fucking do nothin’. Just being friendly that’s all. Brady glares back at him. Everyone seems shocked by Brady behavior. It has come out of nowhere and seems completely of character.
Calm down, Brady. Calm down. Cat pushes Brady aside.
Tanner don’t mean nothin’ by it.

Fuck man! What the hell? Tanner fixes his jacket. Cat looks at Brady, surprised as anyone by his actions. Brady composes himself, also shocked by his own aggressio He feels the eyes of everyone on him. He looks away and quickly storms out.
Brady catches up with Terri Dawn and Lilly.
Lilly, you aright?
I'm fine, Brady. Lilly runs to the truck, leaving Brady alone with Terri D She looks at him coldly. He’s embarrassed. A moment later, she sighs and reaches for her pocket. She pulls out a joint.
This is what you need right now. She signals him to follow and walks away, leaving Brady standing alone in the red neon light.  30.

The pale, bright moon is high in the sky. Coyotes howl from the distant Badlands. Lilly is playing with her recorder in the front seat. Hum softly a melody she made up. Brady and Terri Dawn share a joint in the bed of the truc Their faces lit dimly by the red neon light of the bar. B stoned. Brady leans forward to check on Lilly.
Lil, you hear them coyotes howling?
Yes!
Are you cold?
No, I’m not cold. Guess what?
What?
You're the greatest adventure. Terri Dawn takes a drag of the joint and coughs. She pass it to Brady.
The problem with you boys... You don't like to get your pride hurt.
He was making fun of Lilly.
No, he wasn’t. You know, we don’t care how she is. She don’t care how she is. Brady leans his head back, too high to argue. A moment la

We all love her. I think you’re embarrassed of her. Not us.  31. Brady looks over at her for a moment. He moves clumsily towards her and leans forward. She is a little surprised doesn’t move away. He kisses her on the cheek and lowers head into her lap. She maternally strokes his hair as he closes his eyes. INT. BRADY’S BEDROOM - NEXT DAY Gold star stickers are carefully applied onto Brady’s che Lilly is putting them on him while he sleeps. LOUD KNOCKS. She giggles and quickly scurries out of the room. Brady struggles to open his eyes.

Brady opens the door, still half asleep, covered in star stickers. MILES, a middle-aged, rough looking landlord and debt collector, with a red face and steely blue eyes, gives hi stern look as he passes. His young song, at most 12 year stands behind him with the same annoyed look on his chubb face, clearly emulating his pops.
Hey Miles. What’s goin’ on guys? They pass Brady and walk into the trailer.
Miles struts around the trailer like he owns it - which h does. He checks the light switches.
Looking for your dad. Brady wipes his face.
He went to the horse sale yesterday. I haven’t seen him.
He owes me quite a bit of money on this trailer. I need payment.  32. Brady hides his surprise.
